questions.question_text_1: General Instructions:  (i) All questions are compulsory.  (ii) For long-answer type questions, the word limit and marks for each question are mentioned alongside it. The answers can be short and to the point. So, think for 80% of the time and the remaining 20% for typing.  Refrain from looking at the neighbouring candidate's screen and reproducing their answers. Such behaviour is easily detectable and may attract penalties. Please be mindful that irrelevant answers, responding with unrelated content or duplicating information already provided in the question paper will not earn you marks. Focus on delivering accurate answers, drawing on your learning and personal or professional context.  (iii) For multiple choice questions, each question carries one mark.

The answers can be short and to the point. So, think for 80% of the time and the remaining 20% for typing.  Refrain from looking at the neighbouring candidate's screen and reproducing their answers. Such behaviour is easily detectable and may attract penalties. Please be mindful that irrelevant answers, responding with unrelated content or duplicating information already provided in the question paper will not earn you marks. Focus on delivering accurate answers, drawing on your learning and personal or professional context.  (iii) For multiple choice questions, each question carries one mark.

questions.question_text_1: Explore the application of any four of Howard Gardner’s multiple intelligences in your current profession or towards attaining your career goals. . (Answer in 100 words, 4 marks)  Guidelines: Choose any 4 intelligences and elucidate how they help in your present job (say, if you are a seasoned professional) or shape your career path (if you are a student/ started/ restarting career).
question_texts: Explore the application of any four of Howard Gardner’s multiple intelligences in your current profession or towards attaining your career goals. . (Answer in 100 words, 4 marks)  Guidelines: Choose any 4 intelligences and elucidate how they help in your present job (say, if you are a seasoned professional) or shape your career path (if you are a student/ started/ restarting career).

questions.question_text_1: Read the fictionalized caselet given below and answer the question that follows:  Sankaran is a student in an online Undergraduate Degree program. He has been posting negative, unsubstantiated comments about the program and its courses on a social media platform. Sankaran was found mocking the curriculum, pedagogy, and content of certain courses. Furthermore, he inadvertently incited other learners to support his perspective on the platform.  A concerned fellow student, who wishes to remain anonymous, has brought this matter to the attention of the Student Affairs Coordinator (SAC). They now have enough proof to identify and track the person responsible for the posts on social platforms. The SAC has verified that the posts were indeed made by Sankaran and that it is harming the reputation of the program. Additionally, the SAC discovered that Sankaran has not utilized any of the grievance redressal mechanisms or feedback channels available to him for voicing his concerns or suggestions for improvement. Instead, he has chosen to defame and slander the program. It seems he is unaware of the program's non-academic misconduct policies, modelled after corporate social media guidelines, which appear to be ineffective or not well-enforced in addressing such issues.  As the program gears up for upcoming placements, timing is crucial. Many learners, including Sankaran, have applied for opportunities. It is a well-known fact that hiring managers increasingly scrutinize the online behaviour of applicants. Such posts have caused discomfort to his peers, who are potential employees for the numerous visiting companies.  Question: Discuss the ethical implications of such behaviour on the social platform. What action should SAC take to address this issue? (Answer in 100 words, 4 marks)  Guidelines: You can support your answer based on your own professional experience or learnings from “Case Study: Should He Be Fired for That Facebook Post? by Mary Anne Watson and Gabrielle R. Lopiano.”
question_texts: Read the fictionalized caselet given below and answer the question that follows:  Sankaran is a student in an online Undergraduate Degree program. He has been posting negative, unsubstantiated comments about the program and its courses on a social media platform. Sankaran was found mocking the curriculum, pedagogy, and content of certain courses. Furthermore, he inadvertently incited other learners to support his perspective on the platform.  A concerned fellow student, who wishes to remain anonymous, has brought this matter to the attention of the Student Affairs Coordinator (SAC). They now have enough proof to identify and track the person responsible for the posts on social platforms. The SAC has verified that the posts were indeed made by Sankaran and that it is harming the reputation of the program. Additionally, the SAC discovered that Sankaran has not utilized any of the grievance redressal mechanisms or feedback channels available to him for voicing his concerns or suggestions for improvement. Instead, he has chosen to defame and slander the program. It seems he is unaware of the program's non-academic misconduct policies, modelled after corporate social media guidelines, which appear to be ineffective or not well-enforced in addressing such issues.  As the program gears up for upcoming placements, timing is crucial. Many learners, including Sankaran, have applied for opportunities. It is a well-known fact that hiring managers increasingly scrutinize the online behaviour of applicants. Such posts have caused discomfort to his peers, who are potential employees for the numerous visiting companies.  Question: Discuss the ethical implications of such behaviour on the social platform. What action should SAC take to address this issue? (Answer in 100 words, 4 marks)  Guidelines: You can support your answer based on your own professional experience or learnings from “Case Study: Should He Be Fired for That Facebook Post? by Mary Anne Watson and Gabrielle R. Lopiano.”

questions.question_text_1: Explain the creative process and illustrate it with an example that demonstrates how this process unfolds in practice. (Answer in 200 words, 6 marks)   Guidelines: Focus your response on the 6-7 steps in the process of creativity.
question_texts: Explain the creative process and illustrate it with an example that demonstrates how this process unfolds in practice. (Answer in 200 words, 6 marks)   Guidelines: Focus your response on the 6-7 steps in the process of creativity.

questions.question_text_1: A. Describe a system, as illustrated in the lectures, using the example of the human digestive system. (1 mark) B. Explain the principle of systems thinking illustrated by the story of ‘The Blind Men And The Elephant.’ (2 marks) C. Select a systems thinking “habit” and elaborate on how you plan to apply it in your daily life for personal or professional growth. (3 marks)  (Answer A, B, and C combined in 200 words)  Guidelines: Provide a comprehensive response to questions A, B, and C within a total limit of 200 words. For C, select any one out of the 14 habits and elaborate on its application.
question_texts: A. Describe a system, as illustrated in the lectures, using the example of the human digestive system. (1 mark) B. Explain the principle of systems thinking illustrated by the story of ‘The Blind Men And The Elephant.’ (2 marks) C. Select a systems thinking “habit” and elaborate on how you plan to apply it in your daily life for personal or professional growth. (3 marks)  (Answer A, B, and C combined in 200 words)  Guidelines: Provide a comprehensive response to questions A, B, and C within a total limit of 200 words. For C, select any one out of the 14 habits and elaborate on its application.

questions.question_text_1: Organizational Culture: In a global software development company, two distinct team dynamics are observed:  Scenario 1: The Japanese management team insists that their approach is the only approach and tends to overlook suggestions from the Canadian team.  Scenario 2: Conversely, the Canadian team considers their methods to be the best methods and dismisses ideas originating from the Japanese team.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Organizational Culture: In a global software development company, two distinct team dynamics are observed:  Scenario 1: The Japanese management team insists that their approach is the only approach and tends to overlook suggestions from the Canadian team.  Scenario 2: Conversely, the Canadian team considers their methods to be the best methods and dismisses ideas originating from the Japanese team.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Why audience identification is needed for report writing?
question_texts: Why audience identification is needed for report writing?

options.option_text: In order to bypass undesirable readers
So that the writer can adapt the writing to meet their needs
In order to adapt the findings to their liking
In order to frame the discussion in such a way as to gain the most approval forthe findings

You understand your emotions, values, and goals, and recognize their impacton others.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the exam **"Strategies for Professional Growth"**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

### **Core Topics & Key Concepts**
#### **1. Professional Growth & Career Strategies**
- **Howard Gardner’s Multiple Intelligences** (Application in careers):
  - **Linguistic**: Communication (e.g., report writing, presentations).
  - **Logical-Mathematical**: Problem-solving (e.g., data analysis, coding).
  - **Interpersonal**: Teamwork, leadership, conflict resolution.
  - **Intrapersonal**: Self-awareness, goal-setting, emotional regulation.
  - **Spatial**: Design, visualization (e.g., UI/UX, architecture).
  - **Bodily-Kinesthetic**: Hands-on roles (e.g., surgery, sports, manufacturing).
  - **Musical/Rhythmic**: Creative fields (e.g., audio engineering, music therapy).
  - **Naturalistic**: Sustainability, environmental science.

- **Creative Process (6-7 Steps)**:
  1. **Preparation**: Research/gather information.
  2. **Incubation**: Subconscious processing (e.g., brainstorming breaks).
  3. **Illumination**: "Aha!" moment (sudden insight).
  4. **Evaluation**: Assess feasibility/value of ideas.
  5. **Elaboration**: Refine and develop the idea.
  6. **Implementation**: Execute the solution.
  7. **Feedback**: Iterate based on results.
  *Example*: Designing a new app (from user pain points → prototyping → testing).

- **Systems Thinking**:
  - **Definition**: Holistic approach to analyzing interconnected components (e.g., human digestive system as a system).
  - **Principle Illustrated by "Blind Men and the Elephant"**:
    - Each person perceives a part of the system (trunk, leg, tail) but misses the whole. **Moral**: Avoid siloed thinking; consider interdependencies.
  - **14 Habits of Systems Thinkers** (Pick 1 for application):
    - *Example*: **"Seek Multiple Perspectives"** → Before launching a product, gather input from marketing, engineering, and customers.

---

#### **2. Team Dynamics & Organizational Culture**
- **Critical Success Factors for Teams**:
  | **Factor**               | **Missing Factor → Scenario**                          |
  |--------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
  | Clear goals/objectives   | "No one knows what we’re doing." (Q7)                 |
  | Adequate communication    | "No data to make decisions." (Q8)                     |
  | Top management support   | "Team thinks self-management is a fad." (Q9)        |
  | Strong facilitator        | "Lack of guidance in conflicts."                      |

- **Organizational Culture Terms**:
  - **Parochialism**: "Our way is the only way" (Japanese team in Q10).
  - **Ethnocentrism**: Belief in cultural superiority (Canadian team in Q11).
  - **Globalism/Integration**: Synergizing diverse approaches (ideal scenario).

- **Conflict Management**:
  - **Types of Conflict**:
    - **Dysfunctional**: Poor communication, lack of trust (Q15, Statement 1).
    - **Functional**: Minimal conflict sparks creativity (Q15, Statement 2).
  - **Conflict Resolution Styles** (Thomas-Kilmann Model):
    - **Accommodating**: Yielding to others (Nandini in Q16).
    - **Compromise/Avoidance/Competitive/Collaborative**.

---

#### **3. Emotional Intelligence (EQ)**
- **EQ vs. IQ**:
  - **EQ**: Focus on **emotional reasoning, ability, and knowledge** (Q17).
  - **6R Framework** (Q14):
    - **Rationalize**: Process emotions (not suppress them).
    - Other Rs: Recognize, Reflect, Respond, Respect, Redirect.
  - **Empathy** (Q13): Proactively helping a colleague in distress.

- **Growth vs. Fixed Mindset** (Carol Dweck):
  - **Fixed Mindset**: Belief that talent is innate; leads to unethical shortcuts (Q20).
  - **False Growth Mindset** (Q21):
    - ❌ Praising effort *without progress*.
    - ❌ Affirming potential *without enabling growth*.
    - ❌ Blaming mindset *instead of refocusing it*.
  - **True Growth Mindset**: Embraces challenges, learns from failure.

---

#### **4. Financial Literacy**
- **Liquidity Order** (Q18):
  **Physical Currency (most liquid) > Savings Account > Fixed-Term Deposits (least liquid)**.
- **Tax-Saving Investments** (Q19):
  - ✅ PPF, Life Insurance, Home Loan Repayment.
  - ❌ Regular Fixed Deposits (unless tax-saver FDs).

---

#### **5. Engineering Sense (Decision-Making & Planning)**
- **Bounded Rationality** (Q22):
  - People make **satisficing** (good enough) decisions due to limited info/cognitive capacity (vs. optimal choices).
- **Big Picture Thinking**:
  - **Vision Statement** (Q23): Long-term aspirational goal (e.g., "Be the most customer-centric company").
  - **Benchmarking** (Q24): Compare with best practices to set objectives.
- **Technical Auditing** (Q26):
  - Review processes to identify bottlenecks/deficiencies (e.g., code reviews in software dev).
- **Planning** (Q25): Choosing a course of action from alternatives.

---

#### **6. Ethics & Professional Conduct**
- **Ethical Implications of Social Media Behavior** (Q4):
  - **Issues**:
    - Reputation damage (to self/organization).
    - Violation of misconduct policies.
    - Impact on peer morale and placements.
  - **SAC Actions**:
    1. **Educate**: Inform Sankaran about grievance channels and policies.
    2. **Mediate**: Facilitate a dialogue with affected peers.
    3. **Enforce**: Issue a warning or temporary suspension if repeated.
    4. **Prevent**: Conduct workshops on digital professionalism.

- **Audience Identification in Reports** (Q12):
  - Adapt content to readers’ **needs, expertise, and expectations** (e.g., technical vs. executive summaries).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Professional Growth Ecosystem**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Professional Growth] --> B[Multiple Intelligences]
    A --> C[Creative Process]
    A --> D[Systems Thinking]

    B --> B1{Linguistic}
    B --> B2{Logical-Mathematical}
    B --> B3{Interpersonal}
    B --> B4{Intrapersonal}

    C --> C1{Preparation}
    C --> C2{Incubation}
    C --> C3{Implementation}

    D --> D1{Blind Men & Elephant}
    D --> D2{14 Habits}
```

#### **Graph 2: Team Dynamics & Conflict**
```mermaid
graph LR
    T[Team Success Factors] --> T1[Clear Goals]
    T --> T2[Communication]
    T --> T3[Management Support]
    T --> T4[Facilitator]

    C[Conflict] --> C1{Dysfunctional}
    C --> C2{Functional}
    C --> C3[Resolution Styles]
    C3 --> C3a{Accommodating}
    C3 --> C3b{Compromise}
```

#### **Graph 3: Emotional Intelligence & Mindset**
```mermaid
graph TD
    EQ[Emotional Intelligence] --> EQ1[6R Framework]
    EQ --> EQ2[Empathy]
    EQ --> EQ3[Self-Regulation]

    M[Mindset] --> M1[Fixed]
    M --> M2[Growth]
    M1 --> M1a{Unethical Behavior}
    M2 --> M2a{False Growth}
    M2 --> M2b{True Growth}
```

#### **Graph 4: Financial & Decision-Making Concepts**
```mermaid
graph LR
    F[Financial Literacy] --> F1[Liquidity]
    F --> F2[Tax-Saving Investments]

    D[Decision-Making] --> D1[Bounded Rationality]
    D --> D2[Benchmarking]
    D --> D3[Technical Auditing]
```

---
### **Key Equations (Not Applicable)**
This exam is **conceptual/theory-based** with no mathematical equations. Focus on:
- **Definitions** (e.g., parochialism vs. ethnocentrism).
- **Frameworks** (6R, Thomas-Kilmann conflict styles).
- **Processes** (creative process steps, systems thinking habits).
- **Application** (e.g., how to use a growth mindset in conflicts).
